tit.cmt: 読み方は１つにしました。

sen.j: 陰陽五行思想（いんようごぎょうしそう、おんみょうごぎょうしそう）とは、中国の春秋戦国時代ごろに発生した陰陽と五行思想が結び付いて生まれた思想のこと。
sen.e: Inyo [Onmyo] Gogyo Shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Xing Idea) is the idea that linked together yin-yang (positive and negative, light and shade) and Gogyo Shiso (Five Elements Theory) during the Spring and Autumn period and the Warring States period in China.

Inyo [Onmyo] Gogyo Shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Xing Thought) is the idea that linked together the principles of Yin-Yang (positive and negative, light and shade) and Gogyo Shiso (Five Elements Theory) during the Spring and Autumn period and the Warring States period in China.
sen.cmt: idea>thought. princles ofを挿入しました。
sen.e: Inyo (also pronounced Onmyo) Gogyo Shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Xing Thought) is the idea that linked together the principles of Yin-Yang (positive and negative, light and shade) and Gogyo Shiso (Five Elements Theory) during the Spring and Autumn period and the Warring States period in China.

sen.j: 陰陽五行説（いんようごぎょうせつ）、陰陽五行論（いんようごぎょうろん）ともいう。
sen.e: It is also known as Inyo Gogyo Setsu (The Theory of Five Elements in Yin-Yang) or Inyo Gogyo Ron.
It is also known as Inyo Gogyo Setsu (The Theory of Five Elements in Yin-Yang) or Inyo Gogyo Ron.
It is also known as Inyo Gogyo Setsu (The Theory of Five Elements in Yin-Yang) or Inyo Gogyo Ron.

sen.j: 陰陽思想と五行思想との組み合わせによって、より複雑な事象の説明がなされるようになった。
sen.e: A combination of the cosmic dual forces ideology and Gogyo Shiso made it possible to explain more complicated things.
A combination of the cosmic dual forces ideology and Gogyo Shiso made it possible to explain more complicated things.
A combination of the cosmic dual forces ideology and Gogyo Shiso made it possible to explain more complicated things.

sen.j: 十干十二支
sen.e: Jikkan (The Ten Stems) and Junishi (the Twelve Chinese Zodiac)
Jikkan (The Ten Stems) and Junishi (the Twelve Signs of the Chinese Zodiac)
sen.cmt: Signs of the を入れました。
sen.e: Jikkan (The Ten Stems) and Junishi (the Twelve Signs of the Chinese Zodiac)

sen.j: 陰陽五行説の基本は、木、火、土、金、水、（もく、か、ど、ごん、すい、金は「きん」でなく「ごん」と読ませる）の五行にそれぞれ陰陽二つずつ配する。
sen.e: It is the basis of Onmyo Gogyo Setsu that the Ten Heavenly Stems in yin and yang combine in pairs, each pair corresponding to each of the Five Elements; 木, 火, 土, 金, 水 (moku, ka, do, gon, read as 'gon' not as 'kin', sui).

The basis of Onmyo Gogyo Setsu is that the Ten Heavenly Stems in yin and yang combine in pairs, each pair corresponding to each of the Five Elements; 木, 火, 土, 金, 水 (moku, ka, do, gon, read as 'gon' not as 'kin', sui).

The basis of Onmyo Gogyo Setsu is that the Ten Heavenly Stems in yin and yang combine in pairs, each pair corresponding to each of the Five Elements; 木, 火, 土, 金, 水 (moku, ka, do, gon, read as 'gon' not as 'kin', sui).

sen.j: 甲、乙、丙、丁、戊、己、庚、辛、壬、癸、は音読みでは、こう、おつ、へい、てい、ぼ、き、こう、しん、じん、き、と読む。
sen.e: "甲, 乙, 丙, 丁, 戊, 己, 庚, 辛, 壬, 癸" is read as "ko, otsu, hei, tei, bo, ki, ko, shin, jin, ki" by using on-yomi (the Chinese reading of kanji).
"甲, 乙, 丙, 丁, 戊, 己, 庚, 辛, 壬, 癸" are read as "ko, otsu, hei, tei, bo, ki, ko, shin, jin, ki" by using on-yomi (the Chinese reading of kanji).
"甲, 乙, 丙, 丁, 戊, 己, 庚, 辛, 壬, 癸" are read as "ko, otsu, hei, tei, bo, ki, ko, shin, jin, ki" by using on-yomi (the Chinese reading of kanji).

sen.j: 音読みでは陰陽と五行にどう対応しているか分かりにくいが、訓読みにすると、きのえ、きのと、ひのえ、ひのと、つちのえ、つちのと、かのえ、かのと、みずのえ、みずのと、となり、五行が明解になる（かのえ、かのと、は金）。
sen.e: While on-yomi makes it hard to understand how the ten stems corresponds to yin-yang and the Five Elements, kun-yomi (the Japanese reading of kanji) makes it easy to do so because these readings refer to each element; kinoe, kinoto, hinoe, hinoto, tsuchinoe, tsuchinoto, kanoe, kanoto, mizunoe, mizunoto (wood [ki], fire [hi], earth [tsuchi], and metal [ka], water [mizu]).
sen.cmt: 説明として (wood [ki], fire [hi], earth [tsuchi], and metal [ka], water [mizu])を加えました。
sen.e: While on-yomi makes it hard to understand how the ten stems corresponds to yin-yang and the Five Elements, kun-yomi (the Japanese reading of kanji) makes it easy to do so because these readings refer to each element; kinoe, kinoto, hinoe, hinoto, tsuchinoe, tsuchinoto, kanoe, kanoto, mizunoe, mizunoto (wood [ki], fire [hi], earth [tsuchi], and metal [ka], water [mizu]).

While on-yomi makes it hard to understand how the ten stems corresponds to yin-yang and the Five Elements, kun-yomi (the Japanese reading of kanji) makes it easy to do so because these readings refer to each element; kinoe, kinoto, hinoe, hinoto, tsuchinoe, tsuchinoto, kanoe, kanoto, mizunoe, mizunoto (wood [ki], fire [hi], earth [tsuchi], and metal [ka], water [mizu]).

sen.j: 陰陽は語尾の「え」が陽、「と」が陰である。
sen.e: As to yin yang, the ending of a word with the letter 'e' means yang (positive) and the one with the letter 'to' means yin (negative).
In terms of yin-yang, ending a word with 'e' means yang (positive) and ending with 'to' means yin (negative).
sen.cmt: As to>in terms of. the ending of a word>ending a word. the letterを省略しました。
sen.e: In terms of yin-yang, ending a word with 'e' means yang (positive) and ending with 'to' means yin (negative).

sen.j: 語源は「え」は兄、「と」は弟である。
sen.e: Etymologically speaking, the letter 'e' refers to a big brother and the letter 'to' refers to a little brother.
Etymologically speaking, the letter 'e' refers to an elder brother and the letter 'to' refers to a younger brother.
Etymologically speaking, the letter 'e' refers to an elder brother and the letter 'to' refers to a younger brother.

sen.j: 「えと」の呼び名はここに由来する。
sen.e: Hence the name, the 'Eto.'
Hence the name, the 'Eto.'
Hence the name, the 'Eto.'

sen.j: 「えと」は本来、十干ないし干支の呼称だった。
sen.e: Eto' was fundamentally the name of the Ten Stems or the Oriental zodiac.
Eto' was originally the name of the Ten Stems or the Oriental zodiac.
Eto' was originally the name of the Ten Stems or the Oriental zodiac.

sen.j: きのえ、は「木の陽」という意味。
sen.e: Kinoe refers to 'yang of wood.'
Kinoe refers to 'yang of wood.'
Kinoe refers to 'yang of wood.'

sen.j: 十二支にも五行が配されている。
sen.e: The Wu Xing (The Five Elements) is also given to the twelve signs of the Chinese zodiac.
The Wu Xing (The Five Elements) are also applied to the twelve signs of the Chinese zodiac.
The Wu Xing (The Five Elements) are also applied to the twelve signs of the Chinese zodiac.

sen.j: その前提として、四季に対応する五行は、春が木、夏が火、秋が金、冬は水である。
sen.e: With acceptance on this point, the theory of the Wu Xing corresponding to the four seasons is that spring (春) is moku (木), summer (夏) is ka (火), autumn (秋) is gon (金), and winter (冬) is sui (水).
The basic principle of Wu Xing corresponding to the four seasons is that spring (春) is moku (木), summer (夏) is ka (火), autumn (秋) is gon (金), and winter (冬) is sui (水).
sen.cmt: with acceptance of this point>the basic principle
sen.e: The basic principle of Wu Xing corresponding to the four seasons is that spring is moku, summer is ka, autumn is gon, and winter is sui.

sen.j: 土はどこへ来るかというと、各季節の最後の月である。
sen.e: Where is do (土) placed is in the last month of every season.
As for do (土), it corresponds to the last month of every season.
sen.cmt: where...is placed>as for. is placed>corresponds to
sen.e: As for do (土), it corresponds to the last month of every season.

sen.j: 有名な「土用の丑の日」は夏の最終月（土の月、土用）の丑の日（丑は土の五行）ということである。
sen.e: The widely known the 'Doyo No Ushi No Hi' (土用の丑の日, the Midsummer Day of the Ox) is ushi no hi (丑の日, the day of the Ox [one of the twelve animals of the oriental zodiac]; ushi [丑] is Wu Xing of do [土]) in the last month of summer (the month of do, that is, do yo [midsummer]).
The famous 'Doyo No Ushi No Hi' (Midsummer Day of the Ox), occurs in the last month of summer.
sen.cmt: 長くて意味が不明になったので簡潔にしました。
sen.e: The famous 'Doyo No Ushi No Hi' (Midsummer Day of the Ox), occurs in the last month of summer.

sen.j: 各季節に十二支を配すると、次のようになります。
sen.e: Then the twelve signs of the Chinese zodiac could be divided into every season as follows.
sen.cmt: 一文になるように、「次のようになります。」を追加しました。
sen.e: The twelve signs of the Chinese zodiac are divided into seasons as follows.
The twelve signs of the Chinese zodiac are divided into seasons as follows.

sen.j: 春は、二月寅、三月卯、四月辰（五行は木、木、土）
sen.e: Spring consists of the second month and tora (寅, tiger), the third month and u (卯, rabbit), the fourth month and tatsu (辰, dragon) (moku, moku, do in Wu Xing).
For Spring, February is linked with tora (寅, tiger), March with u (卯, rabbit) and April with tatsu (辰, dragon) (moku, moku, do in Wu Xing).
sen.cmt: ２月、３月などをFebruary, Marchのように翻訳しました。
sen.e: For Spring, February is linked with tora (tiger), March with u (rabbit) and April with tatsu (dragon) (moku, moku, do in Wu Xing).

sen.j: 夏は、五月巳、六月午、七月未（五行は火、火、土）
sen.e: Summer consists of the fifth month and mi (巳, snake), the sixth month and uma (午, horse), the seventh month and hitsuji (羊, ram) (ka, ka, do in Wu Xing).
For Summer, May is linked with mi (巳, snake), June with uma (午, horse) and July with hitsuji (羊, ram) (ka, ka, do in Wu Xing).
For Summer, May is linked with mi (snake), June with uma (horse) and July with hitsuji (ram) (ka, ka, do in Wu Xing).

sen.j: 秋は、八月申、九月酉、十月戌（五行は金、金、土）
sen.e: Autumn consists of the eighth month and saru (申, monkey), the ninth month and tori (酉, cockerel), the tenth month and inu (戌, dog) (gon, gon, do in Wu Xing).
For Autumn, August is linked with saru (申, monkey), September with tori (酉, cockerel) and October with inu (戌, dog) (gon, gon, do in Wu Xing).
For Autumn, August is linked with saru (monkey), September with tori (cockerel) and October with inu (dog) (gon, gon, do in Wu Xing).

sen.j: 冬は、十一月亥、十二月子、一月丑（五行は水、水、土）
sen.e: Winter consists of the eleventh month and i (亥, pig), the twelfth month and ne (子, rat), the first month and ushi (丑, ox)(sui, sui, do in Wu Xing).
Finally, for Winter, November is linked with i (亥, pig), December with ne (子, rat) and January with ushi (丑, ox)(sui, sui, do in Wu Xing).
Finally, for Winter, November is linked with i (pig), December with ne (rat) and January with ushi (ox) (sui, sui, do in Wu Xing).
sen.cmt: スペース挿入しました。日本語削除しました。

sen.j: 十二支の陰陽は、子から数えていき、奇数番目は陽、偶数番目は陰となる。
sen.e: In yin and yang of the twelve signs of the Chinese zodiac, ne (子) should be counted first, the odd-numbered is regarded as yang, and the even-numbered is regarded as yin.
In yin and yang of the twelve signs of the Chinese zodiac, counting begins with ne (子), and odd-numbers are regarded as yang whilst even-numbers are regarded as yin.
sen.cmt: should be counted first>counting begins with. odd-numbered>odd numbers
sen.e: In yin and yang of the twelve signs of the Chinese zodiac, counting begins with ne (子), and odd-numbers are regarded as yang whilst even-numbers are regarded as yin.

sen.j: 十干と十二支が組み合わさるとき、陰と陽の組み合わせはなく、陽と陽、陰と陰の組み合わせのみとなる。
sen.e: When the ten stems and the twelve signs of the Chinese zodiac are used together, any combination of yin and yang could not be made, but all the combinations of yin and yin or yang and yang could be.
When the ten stems and the twelve signs of the Chinese zodiac are used together, yin and yang cannot be combined, however any combination of yin and yin or yang and yang is possible.
sen.cmt: could not be made>cannot be combined. combinations>combination
sen.e: When the ten stems and the twelve signs of the Chinese zodiac are used together, yin and yang cannot be combined, however any combination of yin and yin or yang and yang is possible.

sen.j: そのため、10×12120とはならず、半分の60通りになる。
sen.e: That is why there are sixty possible ways of combinations being half of one hundred and twenty ways, without being composed of ten times twelve.
sen.cmt: 文脈から10×12＝120だと判断しました。
sen.e: That is why there are only sixty possible combinations, not 120 (10x12).
That is why there are only sixty possible combinations, not 120 (10x12).

sen.j: 甲寅はあっても乙寅はない、乙卯はあっても甲卯はない。
sen.e: They have kinote-tora but no kinoto-tora, and have kinoto-u but no kinote-u.
Kinote-tora is possible but no kinoto-tora, and kinoto-u but no kinote-u.
Kinote-tora is possible but no kinoto-tora, and kinoto-u but no kinote-u.

sen.j: 暦
sen.e: Reki (the Traditional Calendar)
Reki (the Traditional Calendar)
Reki (the traditional calendar)
sen.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 陰陽五行説の暦、またそれをもとにした占いは、立春を一年の始まりとしている。
sen.e: Risshun (立春, the first day of spring) is considered as the beginning of the year in the traditional calendar of Inyo Gogyo Setsu or the Chinese astrology based on it.
Risshun (立春, the first day of spring) is considered as the beginning of the year in the traditional calendar of Inyo Gogyo Setsu and the Chinese astrology centered around it.
Risshun (the first day of spring) is considered as the beginning of the year in the traditional calendar of Inyo Gogyo Setsu and the Chinese astrology centered around it.

sen.j: また月の始まりも1日ではなく、二十四節気のうち月の前半に来る十二の節が月の始めになる。
sen.e: In addition, the starting point of each month is not the first day but the 12 setsu points in the first half of the month of Nijushisekki (the 24 divisions of the old calenda, the 24 solar terms).
In addition, the starting point of each month is not the first day but the 12th of 24 'setsu' (divisions of the old calendar) in the first half of the month.
In addition, the starting point of each month is not the first day but the 12th of 24 'setsu' (divisions of the old calendar) in the first half of the month.

sen.j: 年によって違うが、おおむね5～8日になる。
sen.e: It depends on the year, but it could be basically from the fifth to the eighth day.
It depends on the year, but it is generally from the fifth to the eighth day on the month.
It depends on the year, but it is generally from the fifth to the eighth day on the month.

sen.j: 月の節入り（せついり）という。
sen.e: It is called tsuki no setsuiri.
It is called tsuki no setsuiri.
It is called tsuki no setsuiri.

sen.j: 立春、2月4日頃
sen.e: Risshun (立春, the first day of spring) is around on February 4.
Risshun (立春, the first day of spring) is around February 4.
Risshun (the first day of spring) is around February 4.

sen.j: 啓蟄、3月6日頃
sen.e: Keichitsu (啓蟄, awakening of insects) is around on March 6.
Keichitsu (啓蟄, awakening of insects) is around March 6.
Keichitsu (awakening of insects) is around March 6.

sen.j: 清明、4月5日頃
sen.e: Seimei (清明, literally, clear and bright) is around on April 5.
Seimei (清明, literally, clear and bright) is around April 5.
Seimei (literally, clear and bright) is around April 5.

sen.j: 立夏、5月5日頃
sen.e: Rikka (立夏, the first day of summer) is around on May 5.
Rikka (立夏, the first day of summer) is around May 5.
Rikka (the first day of summer) is around May 5.

sen.j: 芒種、6月6日頃
sen.e: Boshu (芒種, grain in ear) is around on June 6.
Boshu (芒種, grain in ear) is around June 6.
Boshu (grain in ear) is around June 6.

sen.j: 小暑、7月7日頃
sen.e: Shosho (小暑, small heat) is around on July 7.
Shosho (小暑, small heat) is around July 7.
Shosho (small heat) is around July 7.

sen.j: 立秋、8月7日頃
sen.e: Risshu (立秋, the first day of autumn) is around on August 7.
Risshu (立秋, the first day of autumn) is around August 7.
Risshu (the first day of autumn) is around August 7.

sen.j: 白露、9月8日頃
sen.e: Hakuro (白露, literally, white dew) is around on September 8.
Hakuro (白露, literally, white dew) is around September 8.
Hakuro (literally, white dew) is around September 8.

sen.j: 寒露、10月8日頃
sen.e: Kanro (寒露, late-autumn or early-winter dew) is around on October 8.
Kanro (寒露, late-autumn or early-winter dew) is around October 8.
Kanro (late-autumn or early-winter dew) is around October 8.

sen.j: 立冬、11月7日頃
sen.e: Ritto (立冬, the first day of winter) is around on November 7.
Ritto (立冬, the first day of winter) is around November 7.
Ritto (the first day of winter) is around November 7.

sen.j: 大雪、12月7日頃
sen.e: Taisetsu (大雪, great snow) is around on December 7.
Taisetsu (大雪, great snow) is around December 7.
Taisetsu (great snow) is around December 7.

sen.j: 小寒、1月5日頃
sen.e: Shokan (小寒, the second coldest day) is around on January 5.
Shokan (小寒, the second coldest day) is around January 5.
Shokan (the second coldest day) is around January 5.

sen.j: だから1月の「年の干支」は前年の干支となるし、3月3日の「月の干支」は前月の干支となる。
sen.e: As a result, 'the animal symbol of the year' in January is the same as the previous year's one and 'the animal symbol of the month' on March 3 is the same as the past month' one as well.
As a result, 'the animal symbol of the year' in January is the same as that of the previous year and 'the animal symbol of the month' on March 3 is the same as that of the previous month one as well.
sen.cmt: year's one>that of the previous year.
sen.e: As a result, 'the animal symbol of the year' in January is the same as that of the previous year and 'the animal symbol of the month' on March 3 is the same as that of the previous month one as well.

sen.j: 陰陽五行思想の論理
sen.e: The Logic of Inyo Gogyo Shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Xing Idea)
The Logic of Inyo Gogyo Shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Xing Thought)
The Logic of Inyo Gogyo Shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Xing Thought)

sen.j: 「陰陽五行思想」とは前述の通り「陰陽思想」と「五行思想」を組み合わせたものである。
sen.e: Inyo Gogyo Shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Xing Idea) is a combination of 'cosmic dual forces ideology' and 'Gogyo shiso' as mentioned above.
Inyo Gogyo Shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Xing Thought) is a combination of 'Yin-yang' and 'Gogyo shiso' as mentioned above.
Inyo Gogyo Shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Xing Thought) is a combination of 'Yin-yang' and 'Gogyo shiso' as mentioned above.

sen.j: 「陰陽思想」は古代中国神話に登場する帝王「伏羲」が作り出したものである。
sen.e: Cosmic dual forces ideology' was originated by Emperor 'Fukki' (伏羲, also known as Fukugi) who appears in ancient Chinese mythology.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Yin-yang' was originated by Emperor 'Fukki' (伏羲, also known as Fukugi) who appears in ancient Chinese mythology.
sen.cmt: yin-yangとは英語でも使われているのでそのままで入れました。
sen.e: Yin-yang' was originated by Emperor 'Fukki,' also known as Fukugi) who appears in ancient Chinese mythology.

sen.j: 全ての事象は、それだけが単独で存在するのではなく、「陰」と「陽」という相反する形（例えば明暗、天地、男女、善悪、吉凶など）で存在し、それぞれが消長をくりかえすという思想である。
sen.e: It is the idea that all the phenomena do not exist separately, but exist in a conflicting form, 'yin' and 'yang' (for example, light and darkness, heaven and earth, men and women, good and evil, good fortune or bad), each one repeating rise and fall.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is the idea that all the phenomena do not exist independently, but exist in one of two conflicting forms, 'yin' and 'yang' (for example, light and darkness, heaven and earth, men and women, good and evil, good fortune or bad), each one repeating rise and fall.
sen.cmt: separately>independently. in a conflicting form>one of two conflicting forms
sen.e: It is the idea that all the phenomena do not exist independently, but exist in one of two conflicting forms, 'yin' and 'yang' (for example, light and darkness, heaven and earth, men and women, good and evil, good fortune or bad), each one repeating rise and fall.

sen.j: 一方、「五行思想」は夏 (三代)の創始者「禹」が発案したものであり、万物は「木火土金水」という五つの要素により成り立つとするものである。
sen.e: Meanwhile, 'Gogyo Shiso' was invented by 'U' (禹), who was a founder of the Ka Dynasty (夏 [三代], also translated as the Xia Dynasty), said that all things consists of the five elements, 'moku (木), ka (火), do (土), gon (金), sui (水).'

Meanwhile, 'Gogyo Shiso' was invented by 'U' (禹), founder of the Ka Dynasty (夏 [三代], also translated as the Xia Dynasty), and stated that all things consists of the five elements, 'moku (木), ka (火), do (土), gon (金), sui (水).'
Meanwhile, 'Gogyo Shiso' was invented by 'U,' founder of the Ka Dynasty (also translated as the Xia Dynasty), and stated that all things consists of the five elements, 'moku, ka, do, gon, sui.'

sen.j: 後に斉の陰陽家鄒衍により5つの惑星と、さらにその後様々な事象と結び付けられ、陰陽思想と五行説が統合されて観念的な陰陽五行思想として完成する。
sen.e: Later, Suen (鄒衍), who was Inyoka (the Yin and Yang school of philosophy) of Sei (斉, State of Qi in ancient China), completed the Inyo Gogyo Shiso by combining cosmic dual forces ideology and Gogyo Setsu (the Five Elements Theory), making a connection between Gogyo and the five planets or the various subsequent events.

Later, Suen (鄒衍), an Inyoka (a practitioner of the Yin and Yang school of philosophy) from Sei (斉, State of Qi in ancient China), completed the Inyo Gogyo Shiso by combining Yin-yang ideology and Gogyo Setsu (the Five Elements Theory), making a connection between Gogyo, the five planets and various phenomena.
sen.cmt: who was aを省略し、of>from. event>phenomena
sen.e: Later, Suen, an Inyoka (a practitioner of the Yin and Yang school of philosophy) from Sei (State of Qi in ancient China), completed the Inyo Gogyo Shiso by combining Yin-yang ideology and Gogyo Setsu (the Five Elements Theory), making a connection between Gogyo, the five planets and various phenomena.

sen.j: 五行相生・五行相剋
sen.e: Gogyo Sosho (The Harmonious Relationship between the Five Elements) and Gogyo Sokoku (Rivalry between the Five Elements)
Gogyo Sosho (The Harmonious Relationship between the Five Elements) and Gogyo Sokoku (Rivalry between the Five Elements)
Gogyo Sosho (The Harmonious Relationship between the Five Elements) and Gogyo Sokoku (Rivalry between the Five Elements)

sen.j: 五行思想の特徴は、「相生」と「相剋」という、それぞれの要素同士がお互いに影響を与え合うという考え方である。
sen.e: A distinctive feature of Gogyo shiso is the idea that the five elements influence each other.
A distinctive feature of Gogyo shiso is the idea that the five elements influence each other.
A distinctive feature of Gogyo shiso is the idea that the five elements influence each other.

sen.j: 相手の要素を補い、強める影響を与えるものを「相生」、相手の要素を抑え、弱める影響を与えるものを「相剋」という。
sen.e: It is called 'Sosho' that each of the elements compensates the others and they mutually affects each other to make them strong and it is called 'Sokoku' on the other hand that they control each other and each of them has an impact on the others to make them weak.
Element which complement and have a strengthening influence on others are called 'Sosho' and elements which control and have a weakening influence on others are called 'Sokoku'.
Element which complement and have a strengthening influence on others are called 'Sosho' and elements which control and have a weakening influence on others are called 'Sokoku.'
sen.cmt: ピリオド位置移動しました。

sen.j: 注意しておきたいのは、「相生」は相手を強めるので常によい、「相剋」は相手を弱めるので常に悪い、という捉え方ではないことである。
sen.e: However, attention should be paid to the aspect that 'Sosho' is not always good as they strengthen each other and 'Sokoku' is not always bad as they weaken each other.
However, attention should be paid to the fact that 'Sosho' is not necessarily good simply because of it strengthens just as 'Sokoku' is not always bad simply because it weakens.
However, attention should be paid to the fact that 'Sosho' is not necessarily good simply because of it strengthens just as 'Sokoku' is not always bad simply because it weakens.

sen.j: 五行相生
sen.e: Gogyo Sosho
Gogyo Sosho
Gogyo Sosho

sen.j: 「木は火を生じ、火は土を生じ、土は金を生じ、金は水を生じ、水は木を生ず」という関係を『五行相生』という。
sen.e: "Gogyo Sosho" refers to the relationship between the elements such as 'wood makes fire, fire makes earth, earth makes metal, metal makes water, water makes wood.'
"Gogyo Sosho" refers to relationships between elements such as 'wood makes fire, fire makes earth, earth makes metal, metal makes water, water makes wood.'
"Gogyo Sosho" refers to relationships between elements such as 'wood makes fire, fire makes earth, earth makes metal, metal makes water, water makes wood.'

sen.j: 木→火→土→金→水→木の順に相手を強める影響をもたらすということが「五行相生」である。
sen.e: It is 'Gogyo Sosho' to bring an influence that makes the other elements powerful in order of the following: wood, fire, earth, metal, water, and wood; Like the way that wood becomes fire after burning, which generates ash (that is earth) that gathers and makes a mountain, where mineral (metal) is produced, and metal returns to water after corroding and then water grows wood.
Gogyo Sosho' expresses the strengthening influence elements have on others in the following order: wood, fire, earth, metal, water, and wood.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Gogyo Sosho' expresses the strengthening influence elements have on others in the following order: wood, fire, earth, metal, water, and wood.

sen.j: 木は燃えて火になり、火が燃えたあとには灰（＝土）が生じ、土が集まって山となった場所からは鉱物（金）が産出し、金は腐食して水に帰り、水は木を生長させる、という具合である。
sen.e: This is symbolised in the way that wood becomes fire after burning, which generates ash (or earth) that gathers to makes a mountain, where minerals (metal) are produced, metal returns to water after corrosion and finally water grows wood.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: This is symbolized in the way that wood becomes fire after burning, which generates ash (or earth) that gathers to makes a mountain, where minerals (metal) are produced, metal returns to water after corrosion and finally water grows wood.

sen.j: 五行相剋
sen.e: Gogyo Sokoku
Gogyo Sokoku
Gogyo Sokoku

sen.j: 「水は火に勝（剋）ち、火は金に勝ち、金は木に勝ち、木は土に勝ち、土は水に勝つ」という関係を『五行相剋』という。
sen.e: "Gogyo Sokoku" means the relationship between the elements such as 'wood defeats earth, earth defeats water, water defeats fire, fire defeats metal, metal defeats wood.'
"Gogyo Sokoku" refers to relationships between elements such as 'wood defeats earth, earth defeats water, water defeats fire, fire defeats metal, metal defeats wood.'
"Gogyo Sokoku" refers to relationships between elements such as 'wood defeats earth, earth defeats water, water defeats fire, fire defeats metal, metal defeats wood.'

sen.j: 水は火に、火は金に、金は木に、木は土に、土は水に影響を与え、弱めるということが「五行相剋」である。
sen.e: It is 'Gogyo Sokoku' that water influences and weakens fire, fire influences and weakens metal, metal influences and weakens wood, wood influences and weakens earth, and more specifically, water puts out fire, fire melts metal, from which cutting tools are made, metal cuts wood, wood shoots through earth, earth holds streams of water.
Gogyo Sokoku' expresses the weaking influence elements have on each other, in that water influences and weakens fire, as fire does metal, metal does wood, and wood does earth.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Gogyo Sokoku' expresses the weakening influence elements have on each other, in that water influences and weakens fire, as fire does metal, metal does wood, and wood does earth.

sen.j: 水は火を消し、火は金を溶かし、金でできた刃物は木を切り倒し、木は土を押しのけて生長し、土は水の流れをせき止める、という具合である。
sen.e: It is symbolised in the fact that water puts out fire, fire melts metal, from which cutting tools are made, metal cuts wood, wood shoots through earth, and earth holds streams of water.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is symbolized in the fact that water puts out fire, fire melts metal, from which cutting tools are made, metal cuts wood, wood shoots through earth, and earth holds streams of water.

sen.j: 日本における陰陽五行思想
sen.e: Inyo Gogyo Shiso in Japan
Inyo Gogyo Shiso in Japan
Inyo Gogyo Shiso in Japan

sen.j: 仏教儒教と同じ5世紀から6世紀に日本には暦法などとともに伝わった。
sen.e: A public office called Onmyoryo (a government office that had jurisdiction over calendar preparation, astronomy, divination, etc.) was built under the ritsuryo system after Inyo Gogyo Shiso was brought to Japan with Chinese traditional culture including rekiho (method of making calendars) from the fitth century, same as the Bukkyo Jukyo (the confucianism of Buddhism) to the sixth century.

Inyo Gogyo Shiso came to Japan in the 5th-6th Centuries along with traditional Chinese culture such as rekiho (method of making calendars), in the same way as Bukkyo Jukyo (the confucianism of Buddhism).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Inyo Gogyo Shiso came to Japan in the 5th-6th Centuries along with traditional Chinese culture such as rekiho (method of making calendars), in the same way as Buddhism and Confucianism.
sen.cmt: 原文に合うよう修正しました。

sen.j: 律令により陰陽寮という役所が設置された。
sen.e: Thus a public office called Onmyoryo (a government office that had jurisdiction over calendar preparation, astronomy, divination, etc.) was built under the ritsuryo system
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Thus a public office called Onmyoryo (a government office that had jurisdiction over calendar preparation, astronomy, divination, etc.) was built under the ritsuryo system.
sen.cmt: ピリオド補足しました。

sen.j: その後、道教の道術を取り入れて、陰陽道へと日本独自の発展をした。
sen.e: Then it developed in a way unique to Japan into Onmyodo (the way of Yin and Yang; the occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements), with the method of a Taoist in Taoism.
From then on it developed in a way unique to Japan into Onmyodo (the way of Yin and Yang), with Taoist methodology.
sen.cmt: then>from then on,; the occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elementsを省略
sen.e: From then on it developed in a way unique to Japan into Onmyodo (the way of Yin and Yang), with Taoist methodology.
